title: Lmod pushenv
body:
Not sure how many people use Lmod's `pushenv()` routine, but we use it in the Lmod hierarchy as a core feature. For example, when a user loads a gcc module, the env var `CC` is set to the spack installed `gcc`. Then a user loads an MPI environment, `CC` is not set for `mpicc` by default. However, we prefer it to do so. So originally, in our modules.yaml file, we'd issue set `CC` to the `mpicc`. But when the user unloaded the MPI module, `CC` was then empty unset because it doesn't know about the previous value for `CC`. With `pushenv()` in as an addtional option `setenv` as an option for Lmod, when the user unloads the MPI environment, `CC` will then be reset to spack installed gcc. 

An example segment in our modules.yaml file would be:
```
    intel:
      environment:
        push:
          CC: icc
          CXX: icpc
          FC: ifort
          F77: ifort
          F90: ifort
    intel-mpi:
      environment:
        push:
          I_MPI_CC: icc
          I_MPI_CXX: icpc
          I_MPI_FC: ifort
          I_MPI_F77: ifort
          I_MPI_F90: ifort
          CC: mpiicc
          CXX: mpiicpc
          FC: mpiifort
          F77: mpiifort
          F90: mpiifort
```

and should result in a module file with following entries (intel and intel-mpi respectfully):

```
pushenv("CC","icc")
pushenv("CXX","icpc")
pushenv("FC","ifort")
pushenv("F77","ifort")
pushenv("F90","ifort")
```

```
pushenv("I_MPI_CC","icc")
pushenv("I_MPI_CXX","icpc")
pushenv("I_MPI_FC","ifort")
pushenv("I_MPI_F77","ifort")
pushenv("I_MPI_F90","ifort")
pushenv("CC","mpiicc")
pushenv("CXX","mpiicpc")
pushenv("FC","mpiifort")
pushenv("F77","mpiifort")
pushenv("F90","mpiifort")
```

Example of the flow as implemented:

```
$ echo $CC

$ module load intel
$ echo $CC
icc
$ module load intel-mpi
$ echo $CC
mpiicc
$ module unload intel-mpi
$ echo $CC
icc
$
```

Without the use of `pushenv()` and over `setenv()` as an option, the environment maintains the original value of `CC`. I think I caught all the pieces for this capability.
